para.sentence: Stokes sets are surfaces (codimension one) in \mathbf{x} space, across which \Psi_{K}(\mathbf{x};k) or \Psi^{(\mathrm{U})}(\mathbf{x};k) acquires an exponentially-small asymptotic contribution (in k ), associated with a complex critical point of \Phi_{K} or \Phi^{(\mathrm{U})}.

The Stokes sets are defined by the exponential dominance condition: \Re\left(\Phi_{K}\left(t_{j}(\mathbf{x});\mathbf{x}\right)-\Phi_{K}\left(t_{ \mu}(\mathbf{x});\mathbf{x}\right)\right)=0, \Re\left(\Phi^{(\mathrm{U})}\left(s_{j}(\mathbf{x}),t_{j}(\mathbf{x});\mathbf{ x}\right)-\Phi^{(\mathrm{U})}\left(s_{\mu}(\mathbf{x}),t_{\mu}(\mathbf{x}); \mathbf{x}\right)\right)=0, where j denotes a real critical point (LABEL:eq:IC.BS.A) or ( LABEL:eq:IC.BS.B), and \mu denotes a critical point with complex t or s,t , connected with j by a steepest-descent path (that is, a path where \Re\Phi=\mathrm{constant} ) in complex t or (s,t) space.
In the following subsections, only Stokes sets involving at least one real saddle are included unless stated otherwise.
The Stokes set consists of the rays \operatorname{ph}x=\pm 2\pi/3 in the complex x -plane.
The Stokes set is itself a cusped curve, connected to the cusp of the bifurcation set: y^{3}=\tfrac{27}{4}\left(\sqrt{27}-5\right)x^{2}=1.32403x^{2}.
The Stokes set takes different forms for z=0 , z<0 , and z>0.

For z=0 , the set consists of the two curves x=B_{\pm}|y|^{4/3}, B_{\pm}=10^{-1/3}\left(2x_{\pm}^{4/3}-\tfrac{1}{2}x_{\pm}^{-2/3}\right), where x_{\pm} are the two smallest positive roots of the equation 80x^{5}-40x^{4}-55x^{3}+5x^{2}+20x-1=0, and B_{-}=-1.69916, B_{+}=0.33912.

For z\neq 0 , the Stokes set is expressed in terms of scaled coordinates X=x/z^{2}, Y=y/|z|^{3/2}, by X=\dfrac{9}{20}+20u^{4}-\frac{Y^{2}}{20u^{2}}+6u^{2}\operatorname{sign}\left(z \right), where u satisfies the equation 16u^{5}-\frac{Y^{2}}{10u}+4u^{3}\operatorname{sign}\left(z\right)-\frac{3}{10} |Y|\operatorname{sign}\left(z\right)+4t^{5}+2t^{3}\operatorname{sign}\left(z \right)+|Y|t^{2}=0, in which t=-u+\left(\dfrac{|Y|}{10u}-u^{2}-\dfrac{3}{10}\operatorname{sign}\left(z \right)\right)^{1/2}.
For z<0 , there are two solutions u , provided that |Y|>(\frac{2}{5})^{1/2}.
They generate a pair of cusp-edged sheets connected to the cusped sheets of the swallowtail bifurcation set (Â§LABEL:sec:IC.BS).
For z>0 the Stokes set has two sheets.
The first sheet corresponds to x<0 and is generated as a solution of Equations (LABEL:eq:IC.SS.D)â(LABEL:eq:IC.SS.Eb).

The second sheet corresponds to x>0 and it intersects the bifurcation set (Â§LABEL:sec:IC.BS) smoothly along the line generated by X=X_{1}=6.9564 3, \left|Y\right|=\left|Y_{1}\right|=6.8133 7. For \left|Y\right|>Y_{1} the second sheet is generated by a second solution of (LABEL:eq:IC.SS.D)â(LABEL:eq:IC.SS.Eb), and for \left|Y\right|<Y_{1} it is generated by the roots of the polynomial equation 160u^{6}+40u^{4}=Y^{2}.
This consists of three separate cusp-edged sheets connected to the cusp-edged sheets of the bifurcation set, and related by rotation about the z -axis by 2\pi/3.

One of the sheets is symmetrical under reflection in the plane y=0 , and is given by \frac{x}{z^{2}}=-1-12u^{2}+8u-\left|\frac{y}{z^{2}}\right|\dfrac{\frac{1}{3}-u }{\left(u\left(\frac{2}{3}-u\right)\right)^{1/2}}.

Here u is the root of the equation 8u^{3}-4u^{2}-\left|\frac{y}{3z^{2}}\right|\left(\frac{u}{\tfrac{2}{3}-u} \right)^{1/2}=\frac{y^{2}}{6wz^{4}}-2w^{3}-2w^{2}, with w=u-\tfrac{2}{3}+\left(\left(\tfrac{2}{3}-u\right)^{2}+\left|\frac{y}{6z^{2}} \right|\left(\frac{\frac{2}{3}-u}{u}\right)^{1/2}\right)^{1/2}, and such that 0<u<\tfrac{1}{6}.
This consists of a cusp-edged sheet connected to the cusp-edged sheet of the bifurcation set and intersecting the smooth sheet of the bifurcation set.

With coordinates X=(x-y)/z^{2}, Y=\tfrac{1}{2}+\left((x+y)/z^{2}\right), the intersection lines with the bifurcation set are generated by |X|=X_{2}=0.4514 8, Y=Y_{2}=0.5969 3. Define Y(u,X)=8u-24u^{2}+X\dfrac{u-\tfrac{1}{6}}{\left(u\left(u-\tfrac{1}{3}\right) \right)^{1/2}}, f(u,X)=16u^{3}-4u^{2}-\tfrac{1}{6}|X|\left(\dfrac{u}{u-\tfrac{1}{3}}\right)^{1 /2}.
When |X|>X_{2} the Stokes set Y_{\mathrm{S}}(X) is given by
Y_{\mathrm{S}}(X)=Y(u,|X|), where u is the root of the equation f(u,X)=f(-u+\tfrac{1}{3},X), such that u>\tfrac{1}{3}.
This part of the Stokes set connects two complex saddles.

Alternatively, when |X|<X_{2} Y_{\mathrm{S}}(X)=Y(-u,-|X|), where u is the positive root of the equation f(-u,X)=\dfrac{X^{2}}{12w}+4w^{3}-2w^{2}, in which w=(\tfrac{1}{3}+u)\left(1-\left(1-\dfrac{|X|}{12u^{1/2}(\tfrac{1}{3}+u)^{3/2}} \right)^{1/2}\right).

There are also three sets of zero lines in the plane z=0 related by 2\pi/3 rotation; these are zeros of (LABEL:eq:IC.CCI.S), whose asymptotic form in polar coordinates (x=r\cos\theta,\;y=r\sin\theta) is given by r=3\left(\frac{(2n-1)\pi}{4|\sin\left(\tfrac{3}{2}\theta\right)|}\right)^{2/3} (1+O\left(n^{-1}\right)), subject to n\to\infty.

section.title: Kelvinâs Ship-Wave Pattern

para.sentence: A ship moving with constant speed V on deep water generates a surface gravity wave. In a reference frame where the ship is at rest we use polar coordinates r and \phi with \phi=0 in the direction of the velocity of the water relative to the ship.

Then with g denoting the acceleration due to gravity, the wave height is approximately given by z(\phi,\rho)=\int_{-\pi/2}^{\pi/2}\cos\left(\rho\frac{\cos\left(\theta+\phi \right)}{{\cos^{2}}\theta}\right)\mathrm{d}\theta, where \rho=\ifrac{gr}{V^{2}}.
The integral is of the form of the real part of (LABEL:eq:IC.UAI.A) with y=\phi , u=\theta , g=1 , k=\rho , and f(\theta,\phi)=-\frac{\cos\left(\theta+\phi\right)}{{\cos^{2}}\theta}.
When \rho>1 , that is, everywhere except close to the ship, the integrand oscillates rapidly.

There are two stationary points, given by \theta_{+}(\phi)=\tfrac{1}{2}(\operatorname{arcsin}\left(3\sin\phi\right)-\phi), \theta_{-}(\phi)=\tfrac{1}{2}(\pi-\phi-\operatorname{arcsin}\left(3\sin\phi \right)).
These coalesce when |\phi|=\phi_{c}=\operatorname{arcsin}\left(\tfrac{1}{3}\right)=19^{\circ}.47122.
This is the angle of the familiar V-shaped wake.

The wake is a caustic of the âraysâ defined by the dispersion relation (âHamiltonianâ) giving the frequency \omega as a function of wavevector \mathbf{k} : \omega(\mathbf{k})=\sqrt{gk}+\mathbf{V}\cdot\mathbf{k}.
Here k=|\mathbf{k}| , and \mathbf{V} is the ship velocity (so that \mathrm{V}=|\mathbf{V}| ).

The disturbance z(\rho,\phi) can be approximated by the method of uniform asymptotic approximation for the case of two coalescing stationary points (LABEL:eq:IC.UAI.K), using the fact that \theta_{\pm}(\phi) are real for |\phi|<\phi_{c} and complex for |\phi|>\phi_{c}.

The physical manifestations of bifurcation sets are caustics.
These are the structurally stable focal singularities (envelopes) of families of rays, on which the intensities of the geometrical (ray) theory diverge.
Diffraction catastrophes describe the (linear) wave amplitudes that smooth the geometrical caustic singularities and decorate them with interference patterns.
See ( ) , ( ) , and ( ) .
Diffraction catastrophes describe the connection between ray optics and wave optics.
Applications include twinkling starlight, focusing of sunlight by rippling water (e.g., swimming-pool patterns), and water-droplet âlensesâ (e.g., rainbows).
Diffraction catastrophes describe the âsemiclassicalâ connections between classical orbits and quantum wavefunctions, for integrable (non-chaotic) systems.
Applications include scattering of elementary particles, atoms and molecules from particles and surfaces, and chemical reactions.
Applications include the reflection of ultrasound pulses, and acoustical waveguides.
See ( ) , ( ) , and ( ) .
Close to the origin \mathbf{x}=0 of parameter space, the series in Â§LABEL:sec:IC.CS can be used.

Far from the bifurcation set, the leading-order asymptotic formulas of Â§LABEL:sec:IC.LOA reproduce accurately the form of the function, including the geometry of the zeros described in Â§LABEL:sec:IC.Z.
Close to the bifurcation set but far from \mathbf{x}=0 , the uniform asymptotic approximations of Â§LABEL:sec:IC.UAI can be used.

This can be carried out by direct numerical evaluation of canonical integrals along a finite segment of the real axis including all real critical points of \Phi , with contributions from the contour outside this range approximated by the first terms of an asymptotic series associated with the endpoints.
